author: James Litston
title: Family holidays in comfort and style
text: With its wide, sandy beaches, wall-to-wall sunshine and truly world-beating attractions, few destinations meet families' needs quite as thoroughly as Dubai . Add in minimal jetlag and non-stop departures from six convenient UK airports and it's easy to see why this cosmopolitan, seaside city is attracting ever more family travellers. Dubai really does have all the essentials for the ultimate family escape. In addition to a world of things to see, do and experience, visitors will find a huge range of accommodation to suit parents and children alike. From beachfront properties and city high-rises with theme parks and attractions attached, to luxury tented camps out in the stillness of the desert, there are hotels here for just about every type of holiday imaginable. One could easily feel overwhelmed when faced with so many options, but specialists like Value Added Travel ensure you make the right choice for your familyâ€™s needs. The company offers a wide range of accommodation for just about every budget and style, and has access to all sorts of deals and discounts throughout the summer months. The obvious choice for families is to stay right on the beach. Value Added Travel offers several properties overlooking pristine sands and the limpid Arabian Gulf. A particular favourite is Atlantis, The Palm, a resort hotel located on a man-made, palm-shaped island. In addition to a world of things to see and do, visitors will find a huge range of accommodation Here, guests have complimentary access to the world-class water park Aquaventure and The Lost Chambers Aquarium. Jumeirah Beach Hotel, attached to Wild Wadi water park, is another excellent choice for families, as is the JA Jebel Ali Golf Resort, home to JA Wibit Water Park and a glorious stretch of sandy beach. For those beach hotels not attached to theme parks, there are kids' clubs and activities to keep younger guests entertained. Le Royal Meridien Beach Resort (and its sister property, Le Meridien Mina Seyahi) both operate a Penguin Club for kids aged four to 12, with complimentary games and babysitting. In addition to its kids' club, the JA Palm Tree Court also has football and movies aimed specifically at teens. Even the sail-shaped Burj Al Arab, the world's first seven-star hotel, caters to fun-loving families with Sinbad's Kids' Club, plus The Hub for its teenage guests. Not everybody wants to stay on the beach, though. For those families more interested in Dubai's indoor attractions, The Address at The Dubai Mall makes a handy base for exploring Dubai Aquarium, Sega Republic and the unusual attraction KidZania - a grown-up world in miniature - within the mall. The Kempinski Hotel Mall of the Emirates, meanwhile, is conveniently located next to Ski Dubai, where you can toboggan down Dubai's indoor ski slope - some rooms are even styled like winter chalets, overlooking the piste! With more than 60,000 hotel rooms (and many more under construction), families cannot fail to find the perfect hotel for their Dubai holiday. And excellent service and faultless facilities ensure Dubai's hotels are the key ingredient to incredible and memorable family escapes.
